016
017package squidpony.squidai.astar;
018
019import squidpony.squidmath.Coord;
020
021import java.util.ArrayList;
022
023/** A {@code Heuristic} generates estimates of the cost to move from a given node to the goal.
024 * <p>
025 * With a heuristic function pathfinding algorithms can choose the node that is most likely to lead to the optimal path.
026 * The notion of "most likely" is controlled by a heuristic. If the heuristic is accurate, then the algorithm will be
027 * efficient. If the heuristic is terrible, then it can perform even worse than other algorithms that don't use any
028 * heuristic function such as Dijkstra. SquidLib's {@link squidpony.squidai.DijkstraMap} is specialized for some cases
029 * that A* isn't, so there are reasons to prefer DijkstraMap when, for instance, you have multiple goals, or the goal is
030 * unchanging for some section of usage but the start point changes often (this is useful for mouse tracking when the
031 * path is reversed). The astar package should be significantly faster when paths are short and always have one goal,
032 * unless you compare it to DijkstraMap when it can reuse a scan and call
033 * {@link squidpony.squidai.DijkstraMap#findPathPreScanned(ArrayList, Coord)}.
034 * 
035 * @param <N> Type of node
036 * 
037 * @author davebaol */
038public interface Heuristic<N> {
039
040        /** Calculates an estimated cost to reach the goal node from the given node.
041         * @param node the start node
042         * @param endNode the end node
043         * @return the estimated cost */
044        double estimate(N node, N endNode);
045}
